thread.title: Maple Leafs sit dead last in ESPN's franchise rankings
thread.title_full: Maple Leafs sit dead last in ESPN's franchise rankings

title: Maple Leafs sit dead last in ESPN's franchise rankings
text:
Leafs dish on first experience playing 3-on-3 OT hockey 
Once again, the Maple Leafs are first at being last, according to ESPN The Magazine. 
The publication ranked all 122 professional teams in the four North American Leagues (NHL, NFL, NBA, MLB), factoring in ticket prices, coaching strength, fan experience, ownership, players, number of championships and 'bang for the buck' when calculating each club's scores. 
The Leafs are the worst team in North America, according to the publication, a dubious position the team has held for three out of the last four years. 
[READ ESPN'S FRANCHISE RANKINGS HERE] 
As a league, the NHL scored highest overall, with 18 teams landing in the top half of the rankings. The Tampa Bay Lightning ranked first among NHL teams and third overall, followed by the Anaheim Ducks at No. 4 and the Dallas Stars at No. 10. 
"No franchise in the four major sports leagues charges more for delivering less ($139 total cost per game for a club that has failed to qualify for the playoffs in nine of the past 10 seasons)," wrote ESPN's Doug McIntyre in the report. 
The Montreal Canadiens ranked 15th among NHL teams, while the Calgary Flames came in at 17th, the Ottawa Senators were 18th, the Winnipeg Jets were 20th, the Edmonton Oilers 28th and the Vancouver Canucks at 29th. 
The Blue Jays were ranked No. 99 overall, 24th among MLB teams, while the NBA's Raptors came in at No. 94 — 22nd in the NBA — tops among Toronto teams. 
The San Antonio Spurs of the NBA were ranked first overall, followed by the Memphis Grizzlies. 
The highest-ranked NFL team is the Seattle Seahawks, at No. 5, while the Pittsburgh Pirates finished tops among MLB teams at No. 8. Poll ESPN crowning the Leafs the worst franchise is... Pretty accurate
